intro: Racosperma imbricatum, commonly known as the mountain wattle, is a flowering plant native to Australia. It belongs to the Fabaceae family, characterized by its compound leaves and pod fruits. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils, often in elevated or coastal regions. Its yellow flowers are clustered in racemes, and it is known for its hardy, drought-resistant nature. Racosperma imbricatum plays a role in stabilizing soil and providing habitat for native wildlife.
